DetailContent.body: Hypotension is commonly due to unnecessarily deep anaesthesia, the autonomic effects of neuraxial block, hypovolaemia or combined causes. You should rapidly exclude a problem in adequate oxygen delivery, airway and breathing first.

DetailContent.head: Box A: CRITICAL CHANGES
DetailContent.body: If problem worsens significantly or a new problem arises, call for help and go back to START of key basic plan →1-1

DetailContent.head: Adequate oxygen delivery
DetailContent.body:
• Pause surgery if possible.
  • Increase fresh gas flow AND give 100% oxygen AND check measured FiO₂.
  • Visual inspection of entire breathing system including valves and connections.
  • Rapidly confirm reservoir bag moving OR ventilator bellows moving.

DetailContent.head: Airway
DetailContent.body:
• Check position of airway device and listen for noise (including larynx and stomach).
  • Check capnogram shape compatible with patent airway.
  • Check airway AND airway device are patent (consider passing suction catheter).

DetailContent.head: Breathing
DetailContent.body:
• Check chest symmetry, rate, breath sounds, SpO₂, measured VTexp, ETCO₂.
  • Feel the airway pressure using reservoir bag and APL valve <3 breaths.
  • Exclude high intrathoracic pressure as a cause.

DetailContent.head: Circulation
DetailContent.body:
• Check heart rate, rhythm, perfusion, recheck blood pressure.
  • If heart rate <60 bpm consider giving anticholinergic drug (Box B).
  • Consider giving vasopressor (Box C) and positioning (e.g. move head down).
  • Consider fluid boluses (250 ml adult, 10 ml.kg⁻¹ paediatric).
  • If heart rate >100 bpm sinus rhythm, treat as hypovolaemia: give IV fluid bolus.
  • If heart rate >100 bpm and non-sinus: →2-7

DetailContent.head: Box C: VASOPRESSOR DRUGS
DetailContent.body:
• ePHEDrine 100 μg.kg⁻¹ (adult 3-12 mg)
  • Phenylephrine 5 μg.kg⁻¹ (adult 100 μg)
  • Metaraminol 5 μg.kg⁻¹ (adult 500 μg)
  • Adrenaline 1 μg.kg⁻¹ (adult 10-100 μg) in emergency only

DetailContent.head: Depth
DetailContent.body: Ensure correct depth of anaesthesia AND analgesia (consider risk of awareness).
Exclude potential surgical causes (Box D) – discuss with surgical team.

DetailContent.head: Box D: SURGICAL CAUSES
DetailContent.body:
• Decreased venous return (e.g. vena cava compression / pneumoperitoneum)
  • Blood loss (unrecognised / undeclared / occult)
  • Vagal reaction to surgical stimulation
  • Embolism (gas / fat / blood / cement reaction)
Consider causes in Box E and call for help if problem not resolving quickly.

DetailContent.head: Box E: DON'T FORGET!
DetailContent.body:
• Consider whether you could have made a drug error
  • Pneumothorax and/or high intrathoracic pressure can cause hypotension

DetailContent.head: Also consider:
DetailContent.body:
• Cardiac ischaemia →3-12
  • Anaphylaxis →3-1
  • Cardiac tamponade →3-9
  • Local anaesthetic toxicity →3-10
  • Sepsis →3-14
  • Cardiac valvular problem
  • Endocrine cause (e.g. steroid dependency)

DetailContent.head: The guidelines in this handbook are not intended to be standards of medical care. The ultimate judgement with regard to a particular clinical procedure or treatment plan must be made by the clinician in the light of the clinical data presented and the diagnostic and treatment options available.
